CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: Integration of the two distinct peaks for all random terpolymers was consistent with the feed ratio of DPP to TPD. The compositions of different terpolymers were also measured by elemental analysis and both values show good agreement. Thermal Properties. The thermal stability of the polymers was investigated by thermogravimetric analysis ( TGA ) , as shown in Figure S2. The TGA revealed that the decomposition temperatures ( T d ) of P1-P7 ( 5% weight loss ) are 405 , 407 , 413 , 417 , 433 , 433 , and 444 °C , respectively. Thus , the thermal stability of the polymers improved as the amount of TPD increased. All of the polymers exhibited excellent thermal stability , which is important for their applications in PSCs and other optoelectronic devices. 35,36 Optical Properties. The optical properties of all the polymers in dilute chloroform solutions and thin films are shown in Figure 2 and summarized in Table 2. All the random terpolymers exhibited multiple absorption bands ranging from 300 to 900 nm , a common feature of polymers based on donor and acceptor units. 37 In addition , all polymers showed broader absorption in thin films compared to in solution due to stronger interchain aggregation. 28 The optical band gaps of P1-P7 were estimated to be 1.38 , 1.38 , 1.40 , 1.42 , 1.49 , 1.55 , and 1.85 eV , respectively , based on the onset of the light absorption. The absorption onset of P7 was blue - shifted compared to P1 , which was due to the weaker electronwithdrawing character of TPD compared to DPP. Upon comparison of the absorption onset of P2-P6 , a similar trend was observed with a gradual blue - shift from P2 to P6 with higher TPD content. In addition , the increased amount of TPD caused the appearance of a new absorption band around 500- 600 nm , which can be attributed to the intramolecular charge transfer ( ICT ) band from BDTT to TPD. On the other hand , the absorption band around 700-800 nm , the ICT band from BDTT to DPP , gradually decreased as the content of TPD increased. By regulating the composition of the electrondeficient units , broad absorptions of the random copolymers , P2-P6 were observed from 400 to 900 nm compared to the parent polymers , P1 and P7 , indicating that incorporating two different electron - deficient units into polymer backbone is an effective method to broaden the absorption band and control the optical band gap. Electrochemical Properties. The HOMO and LUMO energy levels of the polymers were determined by cyclic voltammetry ( CV ) measurements ( Figure 3 ). All CV measurements were recorded in a solution of 0.1 M Bu 4 NPF 6 in nitrogen - saturated anhydrous acetonitrile at a scanning rate of 50 mV / s. The results of the electrochemical measurements are listed in Table 2.

Let's think step by step.

1. DPP - a type of polymer
2. TPD - a type of polymer
3. P1-P7 - different types of terpolymers (made up of DPP, TPD, and BDTT)
4. BDTT - a type of electron-deficient unit
5. Chloroform solutions - a type of material used to measure the optical properties of the polymers
6. Thin films - a type of material used to measure the optical properties of the polymers
7. Bu4NPF6 - a type of electrolyte used in the cyclic voltammetry measurements
8. Nitrogen-saturated anhydrous acetonitrile - a type of solvent used in the cyclic voltammetry measurements

These are the "Material Name" entities in the given paragraph.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. DPP - a type of polymer

3. P1-P7 - different types of terpolymers (made up of DPP, TPD, and BDTT)
4. BDTT - a type of electron-deficient unit
5. Chloroform solutions - a type of material used to measure the optical properties of the polymers
6. Thin films - a type of material used to measure the optical properties of the polymers

Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: Integration of the two distinct peaks for all random terpolymers was consistent with the feed ratio of DPP to TPD. The compositions of different terpolymers were also measured by elemental analysis and both values show good agreement. Thermal Properties. The thermal stability of the polymers was investigated by thermogravimetric analysis ( TGA ) , as shown in Figure S2. The TGA revealed that the decomposition temperatures ( T d ) of P1-P7 ( 5% weight loss ) are 405 , 407 , 413 , 417 , 433 , 433 , and 444 °C , respectively. Thus , the thermal stability of the polymers improved as the amount of TPD increased. All of the polymers exhibited excellent thermal stability , which is important for their applications in PSCs and other optoelectronic devices. 35,36 Optical Properties. The optical properties of all the polymers in dilute chloroform solutions and thin films are shown in Figure 2 and summarized in Table 2. All the random terpolymers exhibited multiple absorption bands ranging from 300 to 900 nm , a common feature of polymers based on donor and acceptor units. 37 In addition , all polymers showed broader absorption in thin films compared to in solution due to stronger interchain aggregation. 28 The optical band gaps of P1-P7 were estimated to be 1.38 , 1.38 , 1.40 , 1.42 , 1.49 , 1.55 , and 1.85 eV , respectively , based on the onset of the light absorption. The absorption onset of P7 was blue - shifted compared to P1 , which was due to the weaker electronwithdrawing character of TPD compared to DPP. Upon comparison of the absorption onset of P2-P6 , a similar trend was observed with a gradual blue - shift from P2 to P6 with higher TPD content. In addition , the increased amount of TPD caused the appearance of a new absorption band around 500- 600 nm , which can be attributed to the intramolecular charge transfer ( ICT ) band from BDTT to TPD. On the other hand , the absorption band around 700-800 nm , the ICT band from BDTT to DPP , gradually decreased as the content of TPD increased. By regulating the composition of the electrondeficient units , broad absorptions of the random copolymers , P2-P6 were observed from 400 to 900 nm compared to the parent polymers , P1 and P7 , indicating that incorporating two different electron - deficient units into polymer backbone is an effective method to broaden the absorption band and control the optical band gap. Electrochemical Properties. The HOMO and LUMO energy levels of the polymers were determined by cyclic voltammetry ( CV ) measurements ( Figure 3 ). All CV measurements were recorded in a solution of 0.1 M Bu 4 NPF 6 in nitrogen - saturated anhydrous acetonitrile at a scanning rate of 50 mV / s. The results of the electrochemical measurements are listed in Table 2.

Let's think step by step.

1. DPP: A type of unit in the terpolymers, possibly a comonomer with TPD and BDTT. Its full form is not provided in the paragraph.
2. TPD: A type of unit in the terpolymers, possibly a comonomer with DPP and BDTT. Its full form is not provided in the paragraph.
3. BDTT: A type of unit in the terpolymers, possibly a comonomer with DPP and TPD. Its full form is not provided in the paragraph.
4. P1-P7: Different terpolymers with varying compositions of DPP, TPD, and BDTT.
5. 5% weight loss: A thermal property used to determine the decomposition temperature of the polymers.
6. Thermal stability: A property of the polymers that describes their ability to withstand heat.
7. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA): A technique used to measure the thermal stability of materials.
8. Decomposition temperatures (Td): A thermal property that indicates the temperature at which a material begins to break down.
9. Optical properties: Properties related to how a material interacts with light.
10. Dilute chloroform solutions: A state of the polymers used to measure their optical properties.
11. Thin films: A state of the polymers used to measure their optical properties.
12. Absorption bands: Optical properties that describe the wavelengths of light absorbed by a material.
13. Onset of the light absorption: A measure of the wavelength at which a material begins to absorb light.
14. Optical band gaps: A measure of the energy required to excite an electron from the valence band to the conduction band in a material.
15. HOMO and LUMO energy levels: The highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy levels of a material, which determine its electrical conductivity.
16. Cyclic voltammetry (CV): An electrochemical technique used to measure the HOMO and LUMO energy levels of a material.
17. Bu4NPF6: A supporting electrolyte used in cyclic voltammetry measurements.
18. Nitrogen-saturated anhydrous acetonitrile: A solvent used in cyclic voltammetry measurements.
19. Scanning rate: A parameter used in cyclic voltammetry measurements that determines the speed at which the potential is swept.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

2. Decomposition temperatures (Td)
3. Optical properties
4. Absorption bands
5. Optical band gaps
6. HOMO and LUMO energy levels
7. Electrochemical measurements

1. Thermal property value: The decomposition temperatures (Td) of P1-P7 are 405, 407, 413, 417, 433, 433, and 444 °C.
2. Optical property values:
   - The optical band gaps of P1-P7 are 1.38, 1.38, 1.40, 1.42, 1.49, 1.55, and 1.85 eV.
